issues.description: The getter name for StockIngredient's name field differs between the template and the solution repositories. In the template, StockIngredient exposes getIngredientName() and Stock.findStockIngredient(...) calls x.getIngredientName(). In the solution, StockIngredient exposes getName() and Stock.findStockIngredient(...) calls x.getName(). This is a signature/name inconsistency across artifacts. Students working from the template will implement against getIngredientName(), while the solution uses getName(), which may confuse students who compare their work to the reference solution or to tests that expect a specific getter name.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the getter name for StockIngredient across the template and the solution. Choose one name (preferably getName() to match the common Java bean style) and update both repositories accordingly: either rename template StockIngredient.getIngredientName() to getName() and adjust template Stock to call getName(), or change the solution to use getIngredientName(). Also ensure the problem statement (or tests) does not require a different getter name, or explicitly document the expected getter name for clarity.

issues.description: The name getter for StockIngredient is inconsistent across artifacts: the template repository's StockIngredient provides getIngredientName(), while the solution repository uses getName(). The problem statement asks students to “add getters for all the private fields” (implying conventional getters) and shows a StockIngredient with a private name field. This creates a naming mismatch for the same conceptual entity (the ingredient's name) across template and solution, which can confuse students when mapping the UML/problem requirement to the provided code and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Standardize the getter name for the ingredient's name across artifacts. Prefer the conventional getName() signature: rename getIngredientName() in the template to getName(), and update all references (e.g., Stock.findStockIngredient) to call getName(). Alternatively, make the solution use getIngredientName() if you prefer the longer form—whichever is chosen, ensure the problem description/UML and both template and solution use the same getter name.
